titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Daniel J. Kevles papers FA497

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-10-01 04:28:15 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Daniel J. Kevles papers

physdesc.extent: 34 document boxes: 33 letter box and 1 half-letter letter box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the research files science historian Daniel J. Kevles created in the preparation and writing of a few of his books.

There are two series in the collection. Each series pertains to a different one of Kevles' books. The first series contains oral history interview transcripts for the book In the Name of Eugenics: Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity (1985). The second series contains various types of materials documenting Kevles' researching the affair surrounding the allegations of scientific misconduct against Thereza Imanishi-Kari and his preparing his book The David Baltimore Case: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character (1998).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection consists of 2 series with the second series further subdivided into 4 subseries.
Series 2. David Baltimore Case Research Files
Subseries 2.2. Case research and book preparation, 1955-2000

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The RAC allows use of the materials in this collection in accordance with the relevant sections of US copyright law that facilitate fair use by scholars. The RAC explicitly does not own copyright for the content of the interviews and, as such, cannot grant permission to publish any component of this material. The responsibility remains with the researcher to obtain permission from the holders of these rights.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to the RAC in several different accessions between 2003 and 2015. These accessions were ingested as Accessions 2003:054, 2011:053, and 2015:108.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: When the collection was first processed in 2015, it contained only the human genetics interviews series. The collection was expanded to include Kevles' research files on the David Baltimore case when those materials were processed in 2024.
The title of the collection was changed from the Daniel J. Kevles papers, Oral History Interview Transcripts to the Daniel J. Kevles papers to reflect the broader scope.

did.unittitle: Human Genetics Interviews

physdesc.extent: 2 document boxes: 1 letter box and 1 half-letter box

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in the series are arranged alphabetically by last name of the interviewee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Daniel J. Kevles, a historian of science, then at the California Institute of Technology, conducted a series of interviews in the early 1980s as research for his book, In the Name of Eugenics: Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity, first published in 1985. As part of his project, he interviewed 39 medical, human, and molecular geneticists from the United States and the United Kingdom. He selected these scientists based on their involvement from the 1930s to 1950s with the process to establish human and medical genetics on an epistemologically-sound footing, devoid of the class and race biases and the methodological flaws that infused the study of human heredity during the heyday of the eugenics movement. Kevles' interviewees included Alexander Bearn, Walter Bodmer, Barton Childs, Harry Harris, Patricia Jacobs, Joshua Lederberg, Jerome Lejeune, Victor McKusick, James V. Neel, Paul E. Polani, Laurence Snyder, and Arthur Steinberg.

did.unittitle: David Baltimore Case Research Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Most of the hearing transcripts in Subseries 2.3 have been arranged chronologically.
Subseries 2.2. Case research and book preparation, 1955-2000

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to Daniel J. Kevles' research and preparation for his book The David Baltimore Case: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character about the investigations into allegations of scientific misconduct against Thereza Imanishi-Kari, David Baltimore's role in the case, and the events surrounding it.

The allegations of misconduct regarded data Imanishi-Kari put into an article for the Science Journal, Cell which Baltimore coauthored ("Altered Repertoire of Endogenous Immunoglobulin Gene Expression in Transgenic Mice Containing a Rearranged Mu Heavy Chain Gene", published in 1986). The allegations originated from concerns raised by a postdoctoral fellow in Imanishi-Kari's laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Margot O'Toole. Investigations and hearings regarding the concerns and the later allegations of misconduct and fraud spanned across several years and were conducted by a number of different organizations, including MIT, the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the United States House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, the Office of Scientific Integrity (OSI), OSI's successor, the Office of Research Integrity (ORI), and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Department Appeals Board (DAB). The conclusion of the case came in 1996 when DAB decided that ORI did not prove its case that Imanishi-Kari committed fraud.

Baltimore is associated with the case because of his refusal to retract the paper and defense of Imanishi-Kari and because of his status and leadership in the scientific community as a Nobel Laureate. A lot of the media coverage and commentary within the scientific community centered him. Also, some of the investigations probed his response to O'Toole's concerns. Because of the controversy, Baltimore resigned from the presidency of Rockefeller University.
Users will see how the file names and documents within the series use terms like the "Imanishi-Kari case" and the "Baltimore case" interchangeably. They all reference these events.

The series is comprised of four subseries. The first subseries contains photographs related to images Kevles used in his book, and it documents his acquiring and deciding the images to incorporate. Materials documenting Kevles researching, drafting, and promoting the book comprise the second subseries. Subseries 2.3 contains transcripts of various hearings regarding the Imanishi-Kari case. Lastly, the fourth subseries has documents pertaining to an article Kevles wrote for the New Yorker about the case ahead of the publication of his book.

In addition to providing insight into the proceedings of the Imanishi-Kari case, the series also documents discussions, controversy, and ideologies about the nature of scientific research fraud and misconduct, the prevalence of it, how it should be responded to and investigated, and the nature of scientific research integrity and ethics.

did.unittitle: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Daniel J. Kelves obtaining and organizing photographs to use in his book The David Baltimore Case: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character. The photographs are mostly of the principal individuals involved in the investigation into the allegations of data fabrication against David Baltimore's co-author Thereza Imanishi-Kari.

The subseries is comprised of two files. The first file contains materials that document Kevles requesting, acquiring, and deciding the photographs he used for the book. There are photo use requests, invoices, correspondence, drafts, and book page mockups. The images in the file include photographs and photograph negatives. Other materials in the file include articles, newsletters, and reports.

The photographs in the second file were organized into a binder. Information attached to the images explain where in the book Kevles intended to insert specific photos. There are also descriptions of who or what is depicted in the photographs and credit information about where the photographs originated.
The subjects of the photographs in the subseries include:

Judith Ballard, David Baltimore, Bruce Chafin, Joseph Davie, Bernard Davis, John D. Dingell, John Edsal, Herman Eisen, Ned Feder, Walter Gilbert, Suzanne Hadley, Jules Hallum, Bernadine Healy, Alice Huang, Briggite Huber, Hugh McDevitt, Joan Press, Mark Ptashne, Bruce Singal, Cecilia Sparks Ford, Walter Stewart, Ursula Storb, Peter Stockton, Tom Watson, Robert Woodland, Henry Wortis, and Julius Youngner.

did.unittitle: Images for book
did.physdesc: File contains still images, including photographs and photograph negatives.

did.unittitle: David Baltimore case photographs (originals)
did.physdesc: File contains still images, including photographs.

did.unittitle: Case research and book preparation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the materials Daniel Kevles acquired and created through his research of the affair surrounding allegations of scientific misconduct against Thereza Imanishi-Kari and his writing of his book The David Baltimore Case: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character.
There are several major components of the subseries. They include:
- Discovery materials prepared by Imanishi-Kari's legal team for her appeal to the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Department Appeals Board (DAB)
- Documents pertaining to the Imanishi-Kari case Kevles obtained under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)

- Proceedings of the different investigations and hearings pertaining to the Cell paper and the Imanishi-Kari case; there are interview transcripts, reports, briefs, findings, and decisions; these investigations and hearings include the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Panel, John D. Dingell's Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce, the Office of Scientific Integrity (OSI), the Office of Research Integrity (ORI), and the HHS DAB

- Interviews conducted by Kevles with individuals involved in the Imanishi-Kari case; there are interview transcripts, notes on interviews, questions for interviews, correspondence and other documents showing Kevles trying to contact individuals, and trip files for visits Kevles made to conduct interviews

- Materials concerning the broader issues around scientific research misconduct, fraud, integrity, ethics, and oversight; these materials largely concern other examples of scientific misconduct investigations like the Robert Gallo HIV discovery case, the efforts of NIH staff members Walter Stewart and Ned Feder to investigate scientific fraud outside of the allegations in the Imanishi-Kari case, procedures and policies for responding to allegations of scientific misconduct, and questions regarding what are scientific research ethics, how serious are issues of scientific misconduct, are instances of scientific misconduct being adequately responded to, and how should scientific misconduct be investigated and handled

- Materials about the impact of the Imanishi-Kari case on David Baltimore; these materials concern Baltimore stepping down from his presidency at Rockefeller University and both support and criticism of Baltimore and his actions within the scientific community
- Media coverage of the Imanishi-Kari case; there are articles and newspaper clippings
- Materials documenting Kevles preparing his book for publication
- Materials documenting Kevles promote his book; this includes media coverage of the book and talks and lectures Kevles gave about the book and the Imanishi-Kari case

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes copies of transcripts from various hearings related to the allegations of scientific misconduct against Thereza Imanishi-Kari.

Most of the files in the subseries pertain to Imanishi-Kari's 1995 appeal of the Office of Research Integrity's (ORI) findings that she conducted scientific misconduct. The hearings were done before the Department Appeals Board (DAB) of the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) between June 1995 and September 1995. DAB decided that ORI had not proven its case against Imanishi-Kari.
Scope and content notes have been added to the individual HHS proceedings transcript files to describe which witnesses were interviewed in those hearing sessions.

Within the subseries, there are also transcripts from several hearings of the United States House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations between 1988 and 1990. The Subcommittee also investigated the allegations of scientific fraud regarding Imanishi-Kari's data in the Cell journal article.
There are some notes included in the files. The notes give insight into how the transcripts informed Daniel Kevles' writing of his book on the Thereza Imanishi-Kari case.

did.unittitle: New Yorker article

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains files that document the background, editing, and aftermath of Daniel Kevles' article "The Assault on David Baltimore". The article was published in the New Yorker in May 1996. Kevles wrote the article about the Thereza Imanishi-Kari scientific misconduct allegation investigations and proceedings while he was researching and preparing his book on the case.

The subseries chiefly consists of drafts, revisions, and galley proofs of the article sent between Kevles and the New Yorker editor Sharon DeLano. Other files show fact checking on the article, comments on a draft by an associate, and promotion of the article through a press release.

There are also materials documenting Kevles' proposal for the article, response to the article, and the influence of the article on Kevles' writing of his book. Responses to the article originated from both the press and individuals involved in the Thereza Imanishi-Kari case. Replies from both Kevles and the New Yorker Letters Editor Josselyn Simpson to these responses are contained in the files.
Correspondence, notes, drafts, galleys, news clips, and articles are found throughout the subseries.
